Overview.Summary: The 2014-2015 Greek presidential election was held in early 2015, with outgoing President Carolos Papoulias unable to stand again (1). The main opposition party chose Maithripala Sirisena as their candidate (2). The ruling party's candidate was former Minister of Health Maithripala Sirisena (2). The election was seen as a gamble for Prime Minister Antonis Samaras (5) and ultimately led to a snap general election (7,10).

Timeline.Text: The Greek parliament fails to elect a new president, triggering a snap election.
Prime Minister Antonis Samaras makes an appeal to parliamentarians to avert snap elections.
The Greek parliament fails for a second time to elect a new head of state.
Stavros Dimas is nominated as the candidate for the first open vote for the presidency.
The Greek government displays its power by securing at least ten votes more than the coalition government's opponent.
The presidential election is planned for the first quarter of 2015 in Greece.
A Greek presidential election makes headlines as the ruling party's candidate normally wins the required three-fifths majority.
Main opposition parties respond to the announcement of the presidential ballot dates and the proposed candidate.
The Eurogroup decides to extend the Greek program by two months ahead of schedule.
Maithripala Sirisena is chosen as the opposition coalition's candidate for the Sri Lankan presidential election.

Overview.Summary: The 2014-2015 Greek presidential election was held as a snap election (1, 8, 9) and involved three rounds of voting (1, 6, 8). The first round, held on December 17, 2014, did not result in a winner with the necessary 200 votes (1). The second round was held on December 23, 2014 and the third round on December 29, 2014 (6). The third round also did not result in a winner, leading to a fourth round in January 2015 (1, 6). The election was ultimately won by Syriza, an anti-austerity far left party (5, 10).

Timeline.Text: A snap presidential election is called in Greece by Prime Minister Antonis Samaras.
The first round of the presidential election is held, with the government's candidate failing to attain the necessary 200 votes.
The second round of the presidential election is held, with the government's candidate again failing to attain the necessary 200 votes.
Sri Lanka's long-time leader Mahinda Rajapaksa is defeated in the presidential election.
Greek national elections are scheduled for January 25th.
The anti-austerity far left party Syriza wins the Greek election by a decisive margin.

Overview.Summary: The 2014-2015 Greek presidential election took place in three rounds (1,2,3) and involved the Hellenic Parliament voting for the president (1,2,3,4,5,7,9). The election was called early by Prime Minister Antonis Samaras (8,9,10) and was characterized by secret agreements, conspiracy talks, shady deals, and political mischief (6). The outgoing Head of State, Carolos Papoulias, could not stand for re-election (4).

Timeline.Text: Greek Prime Minister Antonis Samaras announces the decision to bring forward the presidential election by two months.
The Greek stock market experiences a sharp decline as Prime Minister Samaras calls early presidential elections.
The presidential election is planned for the first quarter of 2015, but is moved up to occur in December 2014.
A history of Greek presidential elections reveals a pattern of secret agreements and political intrigue.
The first round of the Greek presidential election is held, but the government's candidate does not receive enough votes.
The second round of the Greek presidential election is held, but the government's candidate still does not receive enough votes.
In the third and final round of the Greek presidential election, the government's candidate is once again unable to secure enough votes.
The presidential election results in the formation of a new government.
The indirect nature of the Greek presidential election is highlighted as a new government is formed.

Overview.Summary: The 2014-2015 Greek presidential election focused on the Hellenic Parliament (9). The election was planned for the first quarter of 2015 (5) and the term of the previous president, Carolos Papoulias, ended in February (1). The election process has been characterized by secret agreements and political mischief (4). The election was indirect, with members of parliament voting for president (8). The government's candidate for president did not attain the required number of votes in the first and second rounds, leading to a third round (6, 8, 10). The role of the president in Greece is honorary (5) and requires a broad consensus (9).

Timeline.Text: Rumors begin to circulate about a potential snap election in Greece to elect a new president.
Details emerge about the role of the president in Greek politics, as the election date is set for the first quarter of 2015.
The history of presidential elections in Greece is examined, revealing a pattern of secret agreements and political mischief.
The first round of voting takes place in the Greek parliament to elect a new president.
Prime Minister Antonis Samaras offers to call a snap election if the third ballot fails to elect a president.
A second round of voting is held in the Greek parliament, with the government's candidate receiving only 168 of the 200 needed votes.
A third round of voting is scheduled for the following week, as the government's candidate fails to secure enough votes to be elected.
The significance of the role of the president in Greek politics is highlighted, as the election date approaches.
The final results of the Greek parliamentary elections are announced.

Overview.Summary: The 2014-2015 Greek presidential election was planned for the first quarter of 2015 (1). The presidential office in Greece is an honorary one and the role of the head of state is simply honorary (1). The election will go on until a Head of State is finally appointed (5). In 1971, it took 23 rounds of voting to appoint a president in Italy (5). In 2015, the presidential election in Italy was held on January 19 (5). There are several names being discussed for the position of President of the Hellenic Republic (8). The Greek parliament failed to elect a successor to the outgoing President Carolos Papoulias on December 17, 2014 (7). The election was indirect, meaning members of parliament elect the president (3). The election will be held two years ahead of schedule (4). In 1985, it only took one day for Franceso Cossiga to be elected president in Italy (5). In Greece, the president cannot stand for a third term in office (1).

Timeline.Text: The Greek government accelerates the process to elect the next president after eurogroup ministers grant more time to meet bailout terms.

Overview.Summary: The 2014-2015 Greek presidential election was held on January 25, 2015 (3). The election was triggered by the rejection of a presidential candidate in December 2014 (4). The outgoing head of state, Carolos Papoulias, could not stand for re-election (7). The election was seen as a political gamble by Prime Minister Antonis Samaras (8,9) and the results were closely monitored by the European Commission (1). The presidential office in Greece is honorary and does not have the power to dissolve parliament (7).

Timeline.Text: Greek Prime Minister Antonis Samaras announces the early presidential election.
The European Commission officially backs the government candidate in the Greek presidential election.
Greek stocks plunge due to fears of economic instability following the announcement of the early presidential election.
The presidential election is planned for the first quarter of 2015.
The Greek parliament begins the process to elect a new president.
The Greek parliament rejects the government candidate for president, forcing a snap election and risking a bailout.
The Greek national elections are held.

Overview.Summary: The 2014-2015 Greek presidential election took place two years ahead of schedule (2). Incumbent President Mahinda Rajapaksa was seeking a third term in office (2). The opposition coalition chose to field Maithripala Sirisena (2). Former European commissioner Stavros Dimas failed to secure the 180 votes required to be elected president, triggering snap elections (3). The snap elections took place on January 25, 2015 (8). Anti-austerity far left party Syriza won the Greek election by a decisive margin (8).

Timeline.Text: Stavros Dimas fails to secure 180 votes in the Greek presidential election, triggering early elections.
Syriza, an anti-austerity far left party, wins the Greek election by a decisive margin.
Alexis Tsipras, leader of Syriza, declares an end to the 'vicious cycle of austerity' after his party wins the Greek election.
Muhammadu Buhari wins the Nigerian presidential election, becoming the first incumbent to lose an election in the country.
Following a failed attempt to elect a new president, early elections are called for January 25th in Greece.

Overview.Summary: Prokopis Pavlopoulos was elected as the new president of Greece in 2015 (1,2,4,5,6,7,8,9,10). He was chosen by the ruling SYRIZA party and was elected with 233 votes (5). He is an "européen convaincu" and was a former conservative minister (8,10). Pavlopoulos was inaugurated in a ceremony attended by war veterans (3,6). His election was seen as a positive result for the Greek Parliament (7).

Timeline.Text: Former conservative minister Prokopis Pavlopoulos is nominated as a candidate for the Greek presidential election.
The first round of voting for the Greek presidential election takes place, with Pavlopoulos ultimately receiving 233 votes and moving on to the second round.
The second round of voting for the Greek presidential election takes place, with Pavlopoulos receiving a sufficient number of votes to be elected as the next president of Greece.
Prokopis Pavlopoulos is sworn in as the new president of Greece.
On the 194th Greek Independence Day, President Pavlopoulos greets war veterans at a military parade in Athens.

On his first official visit abroad as president, Prokopis Pavlopoulos visits Cyprus and supports their decision to suspend reunification talks after a Turkish vessel entered their exclusive economic zone.

Overview.Summary: The 2014-2015 Greek presidential election was a highly contested event (9) that took place on December 17, 2014 (2,14). The government's candidate, Stavros Dimas, was unable to secure the necessary votes in the first round (2,14,15). The election was seen as a gamble for the ruling party (11) and its outcome could have major implications for the country, including potentially triggering a snap election (8,9,12,13,16,17,19). The European Commission officially backed the government's candidate and applauded the decision to call for a snap election (3). The election was ultimately unsuccessful, leading to a snap general election on January 25, 2015 (8,20).

Timeline.Text: The Greek government announces the presidential election will be held on December 17, two months ahead of schedule.
The European Commission officially supports the government's candidate for president in the upcoming election.
The presidential election in Greece is planned for the first quarter of 2015.
The first round of the presidential election is held, but the government's candidate fails to receive the necessary votes.
The second round of the presidential election is held, but the government's candidate again fails to receive enough votes.
After three rounds of voting, the parliament fails to elect a new president, triggering a snap election.
The presidential election in Italy is compared to the situation in Greece, where a new president has yet to be elected.
Greek President Prokopis Pavlopoulos visits Cyprus and endorses their decision to suspend reunification talks with Turkey.
Presidential elections are held in Sri Lanka, two years ahead of schedule.
Syriza, a party opposed to austerity measures, wins a stunning victory in the Greek general election.
